title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually and in person in New York City.
content: Adolphus Hailstork has bridged vintage classical traditions and multiple genres of American music for half a century. In 2019, the conductor Thomas Wilkins said of the composer’s work: “It’s quite tonal, but it’s not without chromaticism. And some of the time, because he’s sort of hinting at a blues lick or a jazz gesture, we find notes that are bent or twisted.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: For a Composer, the Final Minutes Are Critical
description: Flowering into lushly affecting patterns, Christopher Cerrone’s new album is part of a burst of activity over the past year.
content: Christopher Cerrone’s career got a huge boost right at its beginning: His opera “Invisible Cities,” inspired by Italo Calvino’s novel, was a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize in 2014, when he was barely in his 30s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Mitchell
title: There’s a New Duo That Could Help Rein In Amazon
description: Labor and small business were once natural allies against big business. They should join forces again.
content: In a welcome joining of forces, labor unions and small-business advocacy groups this month supported an antitrust bill that would give New York State sweeping new authority to sue corporate titans like Amazon for abusing their market power in ways that harm competitors or workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Schmidt
title: Mattel joins the NFT frenzy with Hot Wheels digital art.
description: “We need to be on top of current conversations,” Mattel’s president said.
content: Move over, Nyan Cat. Mattel is the latest creator to jump on the hottest craze in cryptocurrency as it puts its first digital art featuring its Hot Wheels vehicles up for sale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Trustbusting Kicks Into Higher Gear
description: Two more signs that antitrust is a big focus on both sides of the aisle.
content: The Department of Justice yesterday filed its first antitrust action since President Biden took office, to block the proposed merger of Aon and Willis Towers Watson. It argued that combining two of the three largest insurance brokers would create an anticompetitive “behemoth.” The $30 billion transaction would “eliminate substantial head-to-head competition and likely lead to higher prices and less innovation,” the department’s complaint said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Climate Change Batters the West Before Summer Even Begins
description: Global warming has been fueling disasters in the region for years. Now, an early heat wave and severe drought are threatening lives and leaving water in perilously short supply.
content: A heat dome is baking Arizona and Nevada, where temperatures have soared past 115 degrees this week and doctors are warning that people can get third-degree burns from the sizzling asphalt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy and Tiffany May
title: Hong Kong Cracks Down on a Pro-Democracy Newspaper
description: Police arrested the top editors of Apple Daily, froze its assets and raided its newsroom, in a sharp escalation of the government’s campaign against dissent.
content: HONG KONG — When the Hong Kong police last year arrested Jimmy Lai, a pugnacious newspaper publisher, they seemed to be going after a longtime government critic. On Thursday, the city’s authorities sent a message to the rest of the media industry: Be careful what you write.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Affordable Care Act Survives Latest Supreme Court Challenge
description: The court sidestepped the larger issue in the case, whether the 2010 health care law can stand without a provision that required most Americans to obtain insurance or pay a penalty.
content: WASHINGTON — The Affordable Care Act on Thursday survived a third major challenge as the Supreme Court, on a 7-to-2 vote, turned aside the latest effort by Republicans to kill the health care law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and David Poller
title: Obamacare, Juneteenth, Comedies: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: As China Scrutinizes Its Entrepreneurs, a Power Couple Cashes Out
description: The husband-and-wife team atop Soho China had already been keeping a lower profile than they did during an earlier, freer era of the country’s economic revival. Now they are selling their real estate business to Blackstone.
content: China’s economy is on a tear. Factories are humming, and foreign investment is flowing in. Even so, the wealthy and powerful people atop some of the country’s most prominent companies are heading for the exits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Hopes Fade for Imminent Federal Deal on College Athletes, Pressuring N.C.A.A.
description: New state laws are scheduled to take effect on July 1, but there are vanishingly low expectations for a deal in Washington in the coming days.
content: WASHINGTON — Congress is not expected to move this month to override a crush of state laws that, as soon as July 1, will challenge the N.C.A.A. rules that have kept college athletes from making money off their fame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: For Republicans, ‘Crisis’ Is the Message as the Outrage Machine Ramps Up
description: With next year’s midterm elections seen as a referendum on Democratic rule, Republicans are seeking to create a sense of instability and overreach, diverting focus from their own divisions.
content: WASHINGTON — House Republican leaders would like everyone to know that the nation is in crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Israeli Officer Who Killed Autistic Palestinian Man Charged With Manslaughter
description: The indictment came more than a year after the fatal shooting. The family of the victim protested the charges as too lenient, calling them “unjust” and “unacceptable.”
content: JERUSALEM — A police officer who fatally shot an unarmed Palestinian man with autism was charged with manslaughter on Thursday, in a case that brought attention to the issue of police brutality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Janet Malcolm, Provocative Journalist With a Piercing Eye, Dies at 86
description: Her subjects ranged widely, but she took special aim at journalism itself, writing that every journalist “knows that what he does is morally indefensible.”
content: Janet Malcolm, a longtime writer for The New Yorker who was known for her piercing judgments, her novel-like nonfiction and a provocative moral certainty that cast a cold eye on journalism and its practitioners, died on Wednesday in a hospital in Manhattan. She was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘12 Mighty Orphans’ Review: A Team Effort
description: Based on a true story of Texas high school football in the Great Depression, this film treats viewers like children.
content: Inspired by a true story of parentless teenagers whose tenacity on the gridiron raised spirits in the late 1930s, “12 Mighty Orphans” is a plodding football drama in which the characters talk to one another like folksy social workers. The condescending tone extends to a voice-over from Martin Sheen, who plays an orphanage physician. He brings viewers up to speed on American history (“It’s hard to remember which came first, the Dust Bowl, or the Great Depression”) and the movie’s message. The team’s coach, Sheen’s character narrates, “knew that football would inevitably bring self-respect to these boys.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Moscow Commentators Celebrate That Biden Sees Russia as a Great Power
description: Cooler heads say President Biden skillfully laid the groundwork for what he can, and cannot, reasonably expect to gain from the Kremlin.
content: GENEVA — For months, Russia’s state news media have ridiculed President Biden as bumbling, confused and well past his prime. But by Thursday, the mood had shifted: Here was a man in the White House, some said, who understands us, whom we can do business with.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Our recommended books this week range from a history of the battle over gay marriage to a memoir of foster parenting to a study of slavery and its aftermath, as seen through the lens of one artifact passed down through generations. There’s a look at Amazon and its founder, a book about the development and evolution of home economics as a discipline, a celebration of the impressive strides humans have made in increasing our life spans. In fiction, we recommend novels about a babysitter’s brush with fame, a town’s fight against toxic pollution and a dead father’s secret second family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jori Finkel
title: The Enslaved Artist Whose Pottery Was an Act of Resistance
description: Poetic jars by David Drake are setting records at auction and starring in art museums, showcasing the artistry of enslaved African Americans.
content: The speckled brown storage jar looks humble, even homely, from a distance — something you might find on a back porch in the South. Come closer and you see the wild runs of alkaline glaze up and down the surface, and some revealing marks by the artist known as Dave the Potter or David Drake, who made powerful stoneware pottery in the Edgefield District of South Carolina while enslaved by different owners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Brontë Auction Is on Hold as Group Tries to Keep Library Intact
description: Sotheby’s has agreed to postpone a highly anticipated auction as a consortium tries to raise $21 million to acquire a “lost” private library for the British public.
content: Sotheby’s has agreed to delay the much-publicized auction of a “lost” library containing rare manuscripts by Robert Burns, Walter Scott and the Brontës, as a consortium of British libraries and museums has begun an effort to raise $21 million to preserve it for the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Yan Zhuang
title: An internet outage affects company websites in Australia and beyond.
description: Analysts said the glitch was caused by service disruptions at a hosting platform, Akamai, based in the United States.
content: The websites for several major corporations in Australia and beyond briefly stopped working for many users on Thursday, in what analysts said was a glitch caused by service disruptions at a hosting platform based in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Saffitz
title: Sponge Cakes You’ll Make Again and Again
description: Claire Saffitz has tips and recipes for a perfectly fluffy dessert that’s as good alone as it is paired with supple summer fruit.
content: Sponge cake doesn’t typically fall high on people’s list of favorite desserts. Its name doesn’t stir the heart, and so often it’s dry and tasteless. But, when properly made, sponge cake is tender and bouncy with a cloudlike crumb that deftly soaks up the flavors of whatever it’s paired with, like whipped cream, coffee or fruit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Hit Hard by Pandemic, Philadelphia Orchestra and Kimmel Center to Merge
description: By joining forces, the two institutions hope to bounce back from the severe losses brought by the coronavirus.
content: The pandemic forced many American arts organizations to resort to mass layoffs and deep pay cuts as ticket sales vanished for more than a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Sticks in the Water
description: Blake Slonecker may wind up all wet.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Some solvers enjoy grid “decorations” (black square art, circled squares, or connect-the-dots themes that create a visual at the end of the solve) and some don’t.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Touré
title: Serena Williams: The Queen and Her Court
description: Gerald Marzorati’s “Seeing Serena” follows her across the globe over the course of one year.
content: SEEING SERENABy Gerald Marzorati
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola and Sopan Deb
title: N.B.A. All-Stars Set a Painful Record for Missing Playoff Games
description: Injury woes are not new, but they have been acute during the playoffs. Never before have eight All-Stars missed at least one postseason game in the same year.
content: Sprained knees. Strained hamstrings. Twisted ankles. Shattered hopes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lovia Gyarkye
title: It’s Not Too Late to Discover Louise Meriwether
description: The author, 98, wrote one of the classic novels of Depression-era Black life, “Daddy Was a Number Runner,” and its themes still resonate today.
content: When Louise Meriwether reflects on her childhood in Harlem, she remembers running around, jumping rope and hanging out with her friends on rooftops, where they would occasionally dare one another to leap from building to building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claudia Gryvatz Copquin and Lisa Prevost
title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: This week’s properties are in Oyster Bay Cove, N.Y., and Fairfield, Conn.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘The Sparks Brothers’ Review: Yes, They’re Real. And Inexplicable.
description: Edgar Wright knows Sparks and you will too, once you see his documentary about this singular cultural phenomenon.
content: Sparks, the musical entity invented and fronted by Ron and Russell Mael, is sometimes rock, sometimes pop, sometimes art song, always idiosyncratic. They’re a cult band with an ever-renewing cult and a career that spans 50 years. “The Sparks Brothers,” an energetic documentary directed by Edgar Wright, explains their appeal in part by emphasizing how it cannot be explained.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Opinion
title: ‘A Spicy Exchange’: Who Won the Final New York City Mayoral Debate?
description: Our columnists and contributors give their rankings.
content: Welcome to the Times Opinion scorecard for New York City’s final Democratic mayoral debate before Tuesday’s primary. A mix of Times writers and outside political experts assessed the performances of the eight leading candidates and rated them on a scale of 1 to 10. One means the candidate should definitely not be running the city or even a Starbucks; 10 means he or she is ready to succeed Mayor Bill de Blasio. Early voting is now underway for those who want to cast ballots before Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Democrats Float $6 Trillion Plan Amid Talks on Narrower Infrastructure Deal
description: Democrats are considering moving unilaterally on a sweeping economic package even as bipartisan talks continue on a smaller infrastructure bill.
content: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats have begun privately weighing a sprawling economic package that could be as large as $6 trillion even as a bipartisan group of senators works to draw support for a much narrower infrastructure plan that would devote $579 billion in new money to fund physical public works projects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: The U.S. and Britain end their aircraft subsidy dispute, mirroring an E.U. deal.
description: The agreement suspends the threat of tariffs related to a spat over subsidies for Airbus and Boeing and turns attention to China’s growing aircraft industry.
content: The United States and Britain have agreed to end a long-running trade spat over aircraft subsidies, and not impose certain retaliatory tariffs for five years, the nations announced on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘Les Nôtres’ Review: Hidden Suffering in Plain Sight
description: In this moody film, a 13-year-old girl in a Quebec town hides her pregnancy, but her trauma deepens as the identity of the father emerges.
content: Jeanne Leblanc’s “Les Nôtres” goes beyond depicting the pain of harboring a terrible secret and into the realm of the numbness that follows. The 13-year-old Magalie (Émilie Bierre) is hiding that she’s pregnant, and when her condition is found out, many in her small Quebec suburb suspect the father to be the boy next door, Manuel (Léon Diconca Pelletier). Gradually the film reveals her connection with another neighbor, Jean-Marc (Paul Doucet), the town’s mayor and an insidious predator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Canadian Couple Who Flew to Indigenous Town for Vaccine Plead Guilty
description: The couple, a gambling executive and an actress, were fined $2,300 for violating coronavirus restrictions but won’t face jail time, court records show.
content: A Canadian couple who drew widespread criticism for flying to a small Indigenous community in January to get vaccinated pleaded guilty on Wednesday to violating local coronavirus restrictions, according to court records.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: These 14 House Republicans Voted Against a Juneteenth Federal Holiday
description: Some objected to the phrase “Independence Day” in the formal name of the holiday celebrating the end of slavery. Others said federal workers did not need another paid day off.
content: When the House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly on Wednesday to make Juneteenth a federal holiday, a day after the Senate rushed the measure through unanimously, 14 House members, all Republicans, voted against the proposal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Backs Catholic Agency in Case on Gay Rights and Foster Care
description: The unanimous ruling was further evidence that claims of religious liberty almost always prevail in the current court.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled unanimously on Thursday that a Catholic social services agency in Philadelphia could defy city rules and refuse to work with same-sex couples who apply to take in foster children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Ted Cruz, I’m Sorry
description: As I leave this job after 10 years, I wish I’d handled many columns better.
content: I owe Ted Cruz an apology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: What Is a Megadrought?
description: Yes, the West is in extreme drought. But for part of the region, conditions have been bad for decades, rivaling periods in the distant past.
content: The Western United States is locked in an extreme drought this year that is one of the worst on record. But for a large part of the region the only thing that makes this year different is the severity of the conditions. Much of the Southwest is in the throes of a megadrought.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
description: An exhibition of work by Hurvin Anderson, silk scarves from Como — and more.
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Nayeri
title: The ‘Divas’ Who Serenaded and Seduced the Arab World
description: A multimedia exhibition in Paris offers a rich flashback to a period between the 1920s and the 1970s when many female performers took center stage.
content: PARIS — The diva sings of love and unmitigated lust. Dressed in a scarlet evening gown with her hair pulled high, she cries out to her beloved, longs for a night of undying passion and yearns for the sun not to rise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Joe Manchin and the Magic 50th Vote for Democrats’ Voting Rights Bill
description: Democrats know that their election overhaul has no chance as long as the filibuster exists, but they are eager to show that all that stands in its way are Republicans.
content: Democrats and progressive activists who have been working for months on a sweeping voting rights bill quickly embraced on Thursday a new, far narrower plan suddenly put forward by Senator Joe Manchin III, their party’s sole holdout on the issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Sweet Thing’ Review: Little Caregivers, Little Fugitives
description: The filmmaker Alexandre Rockwell cast his wife as a negligent mother and his children as runaways in this shimmering black-and-white drama.
content: In the glittering drama “Sweet Thing,” responsible, reserved Billie (Lana Rockwell) loves to sing. She imagines her namesake, the jazz legend Billie Holiday, as a companion and savior. Caregiving is familiar to Billie, who’s a teenager, because the role of protector is one she plays for her younger brother Nico (Nico Rockwell). The pair’s parents are separated, a state of affairs that has plunged their loving father Adam (Will Patton) into a booze-fueled depression. When Adam’s alcoholism lands him in a rehabilitation facility, Billie and Nico are forced to face the darker demons of their mother’s house, where Eve (Karyn Parsons) lives with her abusive boyfriend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Is the U.S. in Crisis? Republicans Want Voters to Think So.
description: Looking ahead to the midterms, the G.O.P. is pushing a message that the country is in peril on numerous fronts.
content: The coronavirus pandemic is receding. The economy is gradually climbing back. And according to recent surveys, a wide majority of Americans is feeling optimistic about the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: Indigenous People Advance a Dramatic Goal: Reversing Colonialism
description: Fifty years of patient advocacy, including the shocking discovery of mass graves at Kamloops, have secured once-unthinkable gains.
content: When an Indigenous community in Canada announced recently that it had discovered a mass burial site with the remains of 215 children, the location rang with significance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: The World’s Dictators Exploit America’s Racism
description: They are not completely wrong.
content: Any Americans who believe that this country’s race problem stops at the water’s edge should disabuse themselves of the notion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Try a great new British mini-series, or plunge back into two returning favorites.
content: Every Monday and Friday, Margaret offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeneen Interlandi
title: From the Times Magazine: Can the C.D.C. be fixed?
description: Last fall, as academics and public-health experts in the United States puzzled over how to make all schools safe for full-time, in-person learning, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention was advising everyone to wear masks and remain six feet apart at all times.
content: Last fall, as academics and public-health experts in the United States puzzled over how to make all schools safe for full-time, in-person learning, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention was advising everyone to wear masks and remain six feet apart at all times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: The Air Quality Index Explained: What It Means and How to Stay Safe
description: Here’s what we know about pollution and a few tips to protect yourself.
content: As dense plumes of wildfire smoke thickened the air in Salem, Ore., last September, residents could barely see down the street, the morning sky glowed an ominous shade of orange and the Air Quality Index soared to almost 500, the worst reading in the United States for the entire year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Nielsen Now Knows When You Are Streaming
description: The company known for measuring television ratings said Netflix and YouTube are far ahead of their digital rivals, but viewers still spend more time watching cable and network TV.
content: Nielsen on Thursday announced that it had moved a step closer toward cracking one of the great questions of the modern entertainment world: How big, exactly, is streaming?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Summer of 85’ Review: Denim Embraces and Stolen Kisses
description: A gay teenagers’s fleeting romance goes off the rails in this coming-of-age story from the French director François Ozon.
content: When the moody, baby-faced Alexis (Félix Lefebvre) capsizes while on a solo trek off the coast of Normandy, France, he looks up and sees lightning in the distance accompanied by a grinning, Adonis-like boy named David (Benjamin Voisin), his savior and the embodiment of the coming storm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Om Gaur
title: The Ganges Is Returning the Dead. It Does Not Lie.
description: Floating corpses in the country's holiest river are Exhibit A for the Modi administration’s failures and deceptions.
content: LUCKNOW, India — The Ganges, or Ganga, is the holiest of India’s rivers, and most Hindus believe that dipping their body in it will purify their soul. But when the second wave of the Covid-19 pandemic hit this spring, the river also became Exhibit A for the Modi administration’s failures and deceptions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: Should N.Y.C. schools be desegregated or improved? Candidates say that’s a false choice.
description: The mayoral candidates were asked during the final Democratic debate whether they would prioritize integrating city public schools or improving them. But many experts would say that’s a false choice. In fact, research has shown that desegregation is a school improvement plan. Decades of attempts to improve city schools at scale without integration have had mixed results, at best.
content: The mayoral candidates were asked during the final Democratic debate whether they would prioritize integrating city public schools or improving them. But many experts would say that’s a false choice. In fact, research has shown that desegregation is a school improvement plan. Decades of attempts to improve city schools at scale without integration have had mixed results, at best.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Steven Erlanger
title: For Biden, Europe Trip Achieved 2 Major Goals. And Then There Is Russia.
description: The president reassured European allies that America is back and rallied them to begin to counter China. Whether he established “red lines” for the Kremlin remains to be seen.
content: GENEVA — President Biden had three big tasks to accomplish on his first foreign trip since taking office: Convince the allies that America was back, and for good; gather them in common cause against the rising threat of China; and establish some red lines for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, whom he called his “worthy adversary.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: A Young Cheyenne Leader Was Beaten Bloody. The Response Brought More Pain.
description: Since Silver Little Eagle was robbed last month, she said she had been bullied and harassed, and failed by the very tribal systems she had campaigned to change.
content: BILLINGS, Mont. — From the moment Silver Little Eagle decided to run for Northern Cheyenne Tribal Council, people dismissed her as too young, too green. But she was determined. Wooing voters with coffee, doughnuts and vows of bringing new energy to tribal issues, she won as a write-in candidate, becoming her tribe’s youngest councilwoman at age 23.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Eva Sereny, Who Photographed Film Stars at Work, Dies at 86
description: She captured De Niro, Streep, Eastwood and many others, often in unguarded moments. Working with directors like Fellini and Spielberg inspired her to make movies herself.
content: In 1972, Eva Sereny was in Rome photographing rehearsals for “The Assassination of Trotsky,” starring Richard Burton as the Russian revolutionary, when his wife, Elizabeth Taylor, who was not in the movie, visited the set.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Juneteenth Was Supposed to Be a Holiday for N.Y.C. Workers. Not Anymore.
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio vowed last year that Juneteenth would be an official holiday. City workers learned this week they would not be getting a paid day off after all.
content: When George Floyd was murdered by the police last May, galvanizing protests for racial justice, efforts to recognize Juneteenth — the day commemorating the end of slavery in the United States — picked up steam across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Honolulu Police Officer Is Charged With Murder in the Shooting of a 16-Year-Old
description: Geoffrey H.L. Thom shot Iremamber Sykap eight times after a high-speed chase on April 5, prosecutors said. Two other officers were charged with attempted murder.
content: A Honolulu police officer has been charged with second-degree murder in what prosecutors called the unjustified fatal shooting of a 16-year-old boy after a high-speed chase in April. Two other officers have been charged with second-degree attempted murder for their roles in the confrontation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: St. Louis Couple Who Aimed Guns at Protesters Plead Guilty to Misdemeanors
description: Mark McCloskey and Patricia McCloskey of Missouri will pay a total of nearly $3,000 in fines and give up the weapons used in the confrontation.
content: A St. Louis couple who gained national notoriety last year after they were filmed pointing guns at demonstrators walking near their home each pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge on Thursday and agreed to pay a total of nearly $3,000 in fines. The couple, both lawyers, also agreed to give up the guns they had brandished in the confrontation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael T. Kaufman
title: Kenneth Kaunda, Patriarch of African Independence, Is Dead at 97
description: As Zambia’s first president, he dominated his country, outliving many of the other frontline leaders who had sponsored southern Africa’s guerrilla wars.
content: Kenneth Kaunda, Zambia’s first president and a founding patriarch of African independence who kept his grip on power for 27 years before enduring electoral defeat, an attempted assassination, house arrest and efforts to deport him from the country he had established, died on Thursday in Lusaka, the nation’s capital. He was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Jeffery C. Mays
title: Yang Faces Backlash for Comments on Mentally Ill
description: The candidates remained focused on crime on the campaign trail, while Andrew Yang was criticized by his rivals for comments he made on the debate stage.
content: Andrew Yang faced criticism over his debate-stage comments about people with mental illness on Thursday as the New York City mayoral candidates sharpened their focus on public safety during the race’s final days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Asked to name their rivals’ worst idea, mayoral candidates fight over defunding the police.
description: The candidates were encouraged to sling a little mud when moderators asked them to name the worst idea they’d heard from one of their competitors.
content: The candidates were encouraged to sling a little mud when moderators asked them to name the worst idea they’d heard from one of their competitors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Sums Up the Biden and Putin Summit
description: “I had a feeling those two weren’t going to make it to the hometown date,” Jimmy Kimmel joked after the leaders cut their meeting short.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Looking for more to watch? Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez
title: Ex-Mayor on Duterte’s ‘Narco Politician’ List Is Killed
description: The death came three days after the International Criminal Court’s departing chief prosecutor requested a full investigation into the bloody war on drugs in the Philippines.
content: MANILA — A former mayor accused of being a drug trafficker in the Philippines was killed Thursday after he attempted to grab a gun from officers while being transported to detention in the capital, Manila, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Physical’ Review: Feeling the Sick Burn
description: Rose Byrne stars in an Apple TV+ dramedy as a seriously bitter woman seeking fulfillment in 1980s San Diego, and starting to find it in an aerobics studio.
content: Let’s take permission from the title of the new Apple TV+ series “Physical” and note the physical appearance of its star, Rose Byrne. This is hard not to do if you watch the 10 half-hour episodes because the show’s go-to shot is a close-up of Byrne: sculpted features, big Pre-Raphaelite eyes, enormous halo of permed curls. It’s as if the camera were asking us, what problems could a woman this attractive possibly have?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Candidates Clash Over New York City’s Future in Final Mayoral Debate
description: The eight contenders jousted over their policies on public safety, homelessness, education and mental illness with less than a week left in the campaign.
content: Clashing over public safety, education and crises of mental health and street homelessness in New York City, the leading Democratic candidates for mayor on Wednesday promoted radically different post-pandemic visions for the city as they made their closing arguments before the June 22 primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: The American Renaissance Has Begun
description: During the pandemic, Americans have been asking existential questions about their lives; now they are changing them.
content: In 1982, the economist Mancur Olson set out to explain a paradox. West Germany and Japan endured widespread devastation during World War II, yet in the years after the war both countries experienced miraculous economic growth. Britain, on the other hand, emerged victorious from the war, with its institutions more intact, and yet it immediately entered a period of slow economic growth that left it lagging other European democracies. What happened?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Price
title: Why Did the Cave Art Vanish? Erased by This Furry Creature and Its Feces.
description: Bats roosting in caves produce ample guano, which may explain why prehistoric marks left by humans cannot be found in some places where they are expected.
content: Hunting scenes, geometric patterns, hand stencils and other works of prehistoric art can endure for tens of thousands of years on the walls of well-protected caves — but only if bats don’t hang out in the galleries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Valby
title: Five Pioneering Black Ballerinas: ‘We Have to Have a Voice’
description: These early Dance Theater of Harlem stars met weekly on Zoom — to survive the isolation of the pandemic and to reclaim their role in dance history.
content: Last May, adrift in a suddenly untethered world, five former ballerinas came together to form the 152nd Street Black Ballet Legacy. Every Tuesday afternoon, they logged onto Zoom from around the country to remember their time together performing with Dance Theater of Harlem, feeling that magical turn in early audiences from skepticism to awe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Fatherhood’ Review: He Lost His Wife. Go Easy on Him.
description: Kevin Hart plays a widower raising a daughter in this Father’s Day Netflix weepie, but the lack of conflict borders on bland.
content: It’s a durable bit of Hollywood conventional wisdom: Behind every good man is a dead woman. “Fatherhood,” a new Netflix movie starring Kevin Hart, is its latest affirmation. A movie widower, especially one with children, draws on a bottomless reserve of audience sympathy, granted the benefit of the doubt far beyond what any woman, however generous or virtuous or grief-stricken, can expect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘A Crime on the Bayou’ Review: Race on Trial
description: Nancy Buirski’s documentary deals with a civil rights case in 1960s Louisiana that wound up before the Supreme Court.
content: As a documentary, “A Crime on the Bayou,” directed by Nancy Buirski, is dryly told, but it has a potent idea, which is to show how even bureaucratic aspects of the legal system in the Deep South in the 1960s could be weaponized against Black Americans. To paraphrase Lolis Eric Elie, a son of a lawyer involved in the events in the film, part of what made Jim Crow totalitarian was its arbitrariness: A Black man never knew when he might suddenly be accused of a crime.
source.name: The New York Times

description: As the June 22 primary approaches, Democratic candidates  sparred over matters of public safety, schooling and homelessness.

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel Strikes Gaza Again, After Militants Set Fires in Israel
description: The exchanges on Thursday and into Friday stopped short of a full-scale escalation, but they underscored the fragile nature of the cease-fire that ended last month’s war.
content: JERUSALEM — Israeli airstrikes hit several sites in Gaza on Thursday night for the second time in three days, after Palestinian militants sent incendiary balloons into farmland in southern Israel for the third day in a row.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cosimo Bizzarri, Rory Smith and Matteo de Mayda
title: In Pandev They Trust
description: North Macedonia is hoping its Euro 2020 campaign can serve as an advertisement for the country, and as a unifying force in a young nation seeking a sense of itself.
content: Goran Pandev’s face is everywhere in Strumica, a sleepy city tucked away in the corner of North Macedonia, not far from the borders with Greece and Bulgaria. It is on the banners around the field at the local stadium. It is painted on the walls of the changing rooms. It beams out from the television screens of dozens of cafes, which faithfully broadcast every game played by the striker’s Italian club team, Genoa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Germany Recalls Platoon on NATO Mission Over Sexual Assault and Racism Claims
description: A tank platoon was sent home from Lithuania after members were suspected of sexual assault, and racist and anti-Semitic behavior, in the latest embarrassment for Germany’s armed forces.
content: BERLIN — Germany’s defense ministry sent home a tank platoon from a NATO mission in Lithuania on Thursday after several of its members came under suspicion of sexually assaulting a fellow soldier, and engaging in racist and anti-Semitic harassment, adding an international embarrassment to a list of woes plaguing the country’s armed forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: 50 Police Officers Step Down From a Crowd Control Unit in Portland
description: The officers voted to leave the unit, known as the Rapid Response Team, hours after one of its members was charged with assaulting a woman at an Oregon protest in August.
content: A group of about 50 police officers who had served voluntarily on a specialized crowd control unit in Portland, Ore., have stepped down from the squad after a year of sometimes violent clashes with protesters, the city’s Police Department said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz and Sarah Kliff
title: Obamacare Is Here to Stay. Brace for New Health Care Battles.

content: The era of existential fights over Obamacare has ended.

description: Biden and Putin meet in Geneva.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Thacher, a California Prep School, Apologizes for Past Sex Abuse
description: In a 91-page report, the private coed boarding school in Ojai detailed sexual assaults and harassment against students dating back to the 1980s.
content: Several faculty members at the private, coed Thacher School in California sexually abused and harassed students or engaged in inappropriate relationships with them, according to a report released by the school, which detailed allegations that went back to the 1980s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Limits Human Rights Suits Against Corporations
description: Six citizens of Mali had sued Nestlé USA and Cargill, accusing the companies of profiting from child slavery on Ivory Coast cocoa farms.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Thursday in favor of two American corporations accused of complicity in child slavery on Ivory Coast cocoa farms. The decision was the latest in a series of rulings imposing strict limits on lawsuits brought in federal court based on human rights abuses abroad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Najim Rahim
title: Elite Afghan Forces Suffer Horrific Casualties as Taliban Advance
description: At least 24 commandos were killed in one battle in the Afghan north, and that kind of stark loss is playing out across the country: “We mourn. The Taliban celebrate. And it hurts too much.”
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — At least 24 Afghan commandos and five police officers were killed after they were surrounded by the Taliban in northern Afghanistan on Wednesday, according to local and Afghan military officials. It was a profound blow to the elite force at a time when such troops often serve as the only units keeping the insurgents from capturing more territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: He Warned Apple About the Risks in China. Then They Became Reality.
description: Doug Guthrie, once one of America’s leading China bulls, rang the alarm on doing business there. He spoke about his time at Apple.
content: Doug Guthrie spent 1994 riding a single-speed bicycle between factories in Shanghai for a dissertation on Chinese industry. Within years, he was one of America’s leading experts on China’s turn toward capitalism and was helping companies venture East.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Candidates differ over how to address homelessness and mental illness.
description: The city’s chronic homelessness has taken on greater urgency over the course of the campaign this spring, as New York has seen an apparent rash of random assaults, often carried out by people who appeared to be homeless, mentally ill, or both.

author: By Tracey Tully
title: A School District Got Rid of Columbus Day. It Didn’t Stop There.
description: A New Jersey school district, criticized for renaming the day for Indigenous people, eliminated the names of all holidays. It might undo that, too.
content: A month ago, the school board in a northern New Jersey suburb followed the lead of at least six other states and scores of municipalities when it voted unanimously to rename Columbus Day as Indigenous Peoples’ Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: Betelgeuse Merely Burped, Astronomers Conclude
description: The dramatic dimming of the red supergiant in 2019 was the product of dust, not a prelude to destruction, a new study has found.
content: Betelgeuse, to put it most politely, burped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Analysis: Biden’s meeting with Putin presented a strained relationship beneath a veneer of civil discourse.
description: By all appearances, President Biden’s much-anticipated meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia was not warm, but neither was it hot.
content: By all appearances, President Biden’s much-anticipated meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia was not warm, but neither was it hot.

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: As Wars Wind Down, Congress Revisits Presidential Powers
description: The House voted to repeal the 2002 authorization for the invasion of Iraq, and the Senate will consider doing so as well in a rare debate over war powers.
content: WASHINGTON — The House voted on Thursday to revoke the authorization it gave in 2002 to invade Iraq, a step that would rein in presidential war-making powers for the first time in a generation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Appropriate Labels for Younger Boomers
description: Must a teenager acknowledge his father, born in 1963, as a member of “Generation Jones”?
content: Glenn writes: My teenager Heath calls me a “boomer.” While I accept that all teenagers despise their parents, I object to the label; I was born in 1963. I grew up with stagflation, Devo and AIDS. Please order Heath to refer to my generation by its correct, dismal name: “Generation Jones.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez
title: Nicaragua Denies Entry to New York Times Journalist Amid Escalating Crisis
description: The refusal to admit the reporter comes amid a nationwide crackdown on journalists, opposition politicians and civil society groups.
content: MEXICO CITY — A New York Times journalist was denied entry into Nicaragua on Thursday amid a nationwide crackdown against the media and civil society in the Central American nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘The French’ Review: A Candid Look at the French Open
description: This documentary by William Klein relies on the unspoken or spontaneous moments to tell the tale of the 1981 Open, off court and on.
content: Bjorn Borg won the French Open in 1981. It was his 11th, and final, victory in a Grand Slam tournament — and the sixth time he won this particular event. An ordinary filmmaker constructing a documentary on the Open that year would likely structure its narrative around the implacable, cool Swedish player’s road to glory there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: After Pandemic and Brexit, U.K. Begins to See Gaps Left by European Workers
description: As the country’s economy restarts after months of closures, staffing shortages have emerged in some industries. The impact of leaving the European Union could be part of the problem.
content: LONDON — Agnieszka Bleka has had to work hard in past years to find companies that need workers, spending much of her day reaching out to local businesses in the northern English city of Preston where she is based.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Is This the Big Tech Breakup We’ve Been Waiting For?
description: Representative David Cicilline’s bipartisan package takes aim at tech companies and would be the biggest antitrust reform in decades. But is it too little, too fragmented and way too late?
content: Representative David Cicilline, Democrat of Rhode Island, is joining forces with Republicans like Ken Buck and Burgess Owens to push through a suite of new antitrust legislation aimed at Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google. If the five bills are passed (without being watered down), they will empower regulators, raise the bar for mergers and acquisitions, and make it a whole lot easier for enforcers to break up businesses. The power of Big Tech is not new, so Kara starts by asking Representative Cicilline: Why did it take so long for Congress to try and catch up?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: At the U.S. Open at Torrey Pines, Tiger Woods Still Looms Large
description: The 2008 championship would be the last major tournament victory for Woods until the 2019 Masters. Rocco Mediate, the golfer he beat in an epic 19-hole playoff, remembers every putt.
content: SAN DIEGO — Arms folded across his chest, Rocco Mediate stared at a small, square television to see if his life was about to change forevermore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandeep Jauhar
title: Turning to Books to Grasp the Most Ungraspable Disease
description: Sandeep Jauhar offers a tour of books about Alzheimer’s, from the search for a cure to fictionalized accounts of living with this scourge.
content: When my family moved to the United States in 1976, the country was in the midst of what could be called the Great Alzheimer’s Awakening. Research conducted that decade suggested that dementia, far from being rare, was actually one of the leading causes of death in American society — just behind heart disease and cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: Was the N.B.A. Season Too Much Too Soon?
description: A rash of injuries leads LeBron James to question the league’s packed schedule.
content: The Los Angeles Lakers will not play another game until October, but LeBron James is apparently not ready to stop dunking. Fresh off the maiden first-round playoff exit of his career, James responded to a cresting wave of injuries to marquee stars with a social media scolding of the N.B.A.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Father and Son Return to the Stage, Together. Again. No Regrets.
description: Reed and Ephraim Birney are in the Berkshires, reprising their roles in “Chester Bailey.” They discuss what it’s like to play off — and fight — each other.
content: In his Instagram profile, Ephraim Birney describes himself as “the black sheep out of work actor in a family of black sheep working actors.” Born and raised in New York, the 24-year-old actor is the elder child of Reed Birney (a Tony winner in 2016 for his performance in “The Humans”) and Constance Shulman (“Doug,” “Orange Is the New Black”). His little sister, Gus Birney, has appeared in the TV series “The Mist” and “Dickinson.” Ephraim Birney has booked jobs, too — “Gotham,” “The Americans” — but not quite as many.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘The Birthday Cake’ Review: Baked Hoods
description: This mob drama folds family secrets and fading power into a story of operatic vengeance.
content: “With tragedy comes strength,” a priest (Ewan McGregor) tells Gio (Shiloh Fernandez) early in “The Birthday Cake,” so we can anticipate trouble. But it’s not the fairly predictable tonal arc that makes this first feature from Jimmy Giannopoulos click: It’s the deftness with which he weaves multiple threads of unease into a single strand of throttling tension.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Fatima Faizi and Lara Jakes
title: The U.S. Embassy in Kabul locks down, hit by a coronavirus outbreak surging across Afghanistan.
description: An official notice said that more than 115 people associated with the embassy had been infected, and that despite access to vaccines, most of those stricken were un- or only partially vaccinated.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The U.S. Embassy in Kabul went into lockdown on Thursday, citing a surge in coronavirus cases that has swamped the medical facilities that remain open to American diplomats as the U.S. military and international forces depart the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: ‘Springsteen on Broadway’ is returning, but not for guests who haven’t had F.D.A.-authorized vaccines.
description: The venue, New York’s St. James Theatre, is making no exceptions for people who are unable or unwilling to be vaccinated.
content: When Bruce Springsteen walks onstage on June 26 in the first show to return to Broadway, his audience will have had to prove that they’ve been vaccinated. And those inoculations have to be with vaccines authorized by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration: Moderna’s, Pfizer-BioNTech’s, or Johnson & Johnson’s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Ohio House Expels Ex-Speaker Charged in $60 Million Corruption Scheme
description: The 75-to-21 vote to expel Representative Larry Householder came nearly a year after he was charged in a wide-ranging conspiracy to bail out a foundering energy company.
content: The Ohio House of Representatives voted on Wednesday to expel a powerful Republican lawmaker, nearly a year after he was arrested and charged in a $60 million corruption scheme while serving as House speaker.

title: Why This Overlooked Residential Island in N.Y.C. Wants Tourists
description: With a tech campus, a chic hotel, ample green space and its famous tram, Roosevelt Island would like more visitors, please.
content: When Med Abrous, a restaurateur behind trendy establishments in Los Angeles, Nashville and Seattle, got the call about opening a restaurant on Roosevelt Island in New York, he almost hung up the phone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Vindman
title: We’ve Come a Long Way Since Trump. Putin Is Still Winning.
description: The overriding U.S. foreign policy aim must be to prevent an existential confrontation with Russia.
content: The last time an American president held a summit with President Vladimir Putin of Russia — July 16, 2018, in Helsinki — happened to be my first day working at the White House as the National Security Council director for European and Russian affairs. It was not the usual mundane Day 1 of H.R. meetings, to put it mildly. Instead, I was thrust into a vortex of unending press inquiries and hasty meetings with other National Security Council staff members. We were all responding to frantic calls from embassies and congressional aides demanding comments and clarification on President Donald Trump’s bizarre assertion that he seemed to believe Mr. Putin’s (false) denials of interference in the 2016 election at least as much as the assessment of the United States intelligence community.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ashley C. Ford Believes in Letting the Light In
description: The podcast host and debut author tells a difficult story in her best-selling memoir, “Somebody’s Daughter.” But there are glimmers of brightness.
content: CHAPTER AND VERSE When you’re opening a new book, do you breeze past the epigraph as if it’s extra credit and you’re in a rush to finish your homework? Slow down! That short quotation is there for a reason: to set the tone and mood, and to give you some insight into a writer’s mind-set. Plus, in some cases the author has paid handsomely for permission to print these words so you might as well read them.

author: By Adam Bradley
title: The Photographer Who Captured the Beauty in Blackness
description: Kwame Brathwaite, who shot some of the great icons of the 1960s and ’70s, has spent his career largely underrecognized. That is, until now.
content: In 2004, while sifting through a box of files with his son, the pioneering photographer Kwame Brathwaite, who chronicled Black life across seven decades, beginning in the 1950s, pulled out a long-forgotten black-and-white image from a manila envelope. It captured a resplendent Roberta Flack in a flowing chiffon gown, John Lennon’s left arm draped atop her shoulder, his right clutching Yoko Ono, with a “plastic soul”-era David Bowie looking on bemused and the Righteous Brothers thrown in for good measure.

description: A new report reveals which U.S. metropolitan areas have the highest percentage of homes valued at $1 million or more.

title: ‘Mediocre’ men get ahead in finance more easily, say women in the industry.
description: Women said they had to find an innovative niche to succeed while men were welcome on more traditional paths, according to a recent qualitative study.
content: This week, the European Central Bank proposed using gender diversity among criteria for approving board members at the banks it supervises. Such mandates are one lever for increasing representation of women in an industry still dominated by men.

title: Katie and Jon Ledecky: Two Sports, Three States, and a Lot of Perfect Timing
description: The Olympic swimmer and her uncle, a co-owner of the Islanders, are competing this week for berths on their biggest stages. A little frantic air travel to cheer on close family is nothing.
content: OMAHA — Katie Ledecky’s summer solstice fell five days early on the calendar, as she traveled her longest path through the United States swim trials on Tuesday by logging 1,900 meters of racing — 2,300 meters in a 24-hour span if you include her laborious victory in the 400-meter freestyle late Monday — and qualifying for a third consecutive Olympics.

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: What to Watch For in the U.S.A. Track & Field Olympic Trials
description: The top three finishers in each event qualify for the Tokyo Games, provided they have reached the Olympic standard.
content: For months, they have trained in relative isolation. They have triple jumped in empty stadiums and chased qualifying standards on high school tracks. You may have heard this before, but the pandemic created challenges for American track and field athletes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Parents and caregivers reported mental health issues more often than others during the pandemic, a C.D.C. study says.
description: The report follows innumerable anecdotes and several studies suggesting spikes in mental health problems among parents and caregivers during the pandemic.

title: Rafael Nadal Says He Will Skip Wimbledon and the Olympics
description: The Spanish star said a short turnaround between the French Open and Wimbledon did not allow enough time for his body to recover.
content: Rafael Nadal, a 20-time Grand Slam tournament winner, will not go for No. 21 at Wimbledon this year, he announced on Thursday. He also pulled out of the Olympics, and in doing so became the latest top athlete to suggest that compressed sports schedules after the pandemic were asking too much of their biggest stars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Zane
title: I Don’t Know Who Needs to Hear This, but You Are Bi Enough
description: We need you. You could use us, too.
content: After telling someone I’m bi, I can’t tell you the number of times I’ve heard, “You know, I’ve never met a bisexual person.” I always reply the same way: “You’ve never met an out bisexual person.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: With Putin, Biden Tries to Forge a Bond of Self-Interest, Not Souls
description: Theirs seems likely to be a strained and frustrating association, one where the two leaders may maintain a veneer of civil discourse even as they joust on the international stage.
content: No one peered admiringly into anyone’s soul. No one called anyone a killer. By all appearances, President Biden’s much-anticipated meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia was not warm, but neither was it hot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Nations weigh mandates and incentives to drive up vaccination rates.
description: While some parts of the world have used lures such as free lottery tickets to lift inoculation rates, officials in a few places may go straight to requiring shots.
content: The coronavirus pandemic has exposed economic and social fault lines around the globe, but Covid-19 vaccines have made the divides even starker: While some poor countries are pleading for doses to save their people, a few rich ones are awash in shots and lacking takers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Guide to Theater Festivals in New York and the Berkshires
description: From the Williamstown Theater Festival to New York Stage and Film, theatergoers can experience world premieres, concerts and more.
content: Most summers, as tourists pour into New York City to see theater, New Yorkers pour out to see theater elsewhere. This summer, though, they may do so with extra ardor. As the pandemic lifts, the pent-up demand for live, in-person theater is first being met in the Berkshires and in the mid-Hudson region, where companies are putting up tents, arranging outdoor immersive experiences and welcoming audiences to buildings that have been empty for too long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sonia Sanchez and Reginald Dwayne Betts
title: Poem: ‘There is no news from Auschwitz’
description: This poem by Sonia Sanchez will astonish and alarm you.
content: This poem, from Sonia Sanchez’s new “Collected Poems,” first appeared in “Under a Soprano Sky,” a book I ordered while in solitary confinement in a Virginia prison. The first poetry collection I purchased, the book became all the clichés for me: my life raft, my rope, my talisman, my four-leaf clover. From the history of the MOVE bombing to reminding me of Auschwitz’s horrors, I got it from that “Soprano Sky.” All these years later, I can nearly see myself flipping through these pages in my sleep, astonished and alarmed by what words might do — amazed to find so much of the world I’d thrown away in the lines that were saving me. Selected by Reginald Dwayne Betts
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Transformation of Ralph Northam
description: How the Virginia governor who was embroiled in a blackface scandal became the most racially progressive leader in the state’s history.
content: In 2019, it seemed to many that Gov. Ralph Northam’s career was over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Farnaz Fassihi
title: Many Expected to Shun Iran Vote Seen as Presidential Race of One
description: An ultraconservative judiciary chief appears to have the only real chance of winning after a council of powerful clerics disqualified virtually all the other viable candidates.
content: TEHRAN — Come presidential election time, the streets of central Tehran are usually wallpapered with the candidates’ names and faces, their banners swaying from buildings and streetlights. But this time around, the biggest banners bear no names, only a simple message: Vote on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: A Quiet Demonstration and a Long Shadow
description: Few noticed Wyomia Tyus’s subtle gesture in support of human rights at the 1968 Olympics. But her act is part of a rich history of athlete protest.
content: To stay loose for the women’s 100-meter sprint at the 1968 Olympics in Mexico City, Wyomia Tyus danced the “Tighten Up” before settling into her starting blocks. The dance song was an early funk classic by Archie Bell and the Drells, a Houston band that proclaimed with jaunty assurance, “We don’t only sing, but we dance just as good as we want.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: A Pill to Treat Covid-19? The U.S. Is Betting on It.
description: A new $3.2 billion program will support the development of antiviral pills, which could start arriving by the end of this year.
content: The U.S. government spent more than $18 billion last year funding drugmakers to make a Covid vaccine, an effort that led to at least five highly effective shots in record time. Now it’s pouring more than $3 billion on a neglected area of research: developing pills to fight the virus early in the course of infection, potentially saving many lives in the years to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: After Putin Meeting, a Biden Trait Shows Itself Again: Stubborn Optimism
description: The president’s insistence on an “optimistic face” could open him up to criticism. But his allies insist it’s an essential ingredient to making progress.
content: GENEVA — Another American president might have been frustrated, or even angry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aiyana Green and Steven Strogatz
title: Who’s Afraid of Big Numbers?
description: Pretty much everyone. But it doesn’t have to be that way, two mathematicians contend.
content: “Billions” and “trillions” seem to be an inescapable part of our conversations these days, whether the subject is Jeff Bezos’s net worth or President Biden’s proposed budget. Yet nearly everyone has trouble making sense of such big numbers. Is there any way to get a feel for them? As it turns out, there is. If we can relate big numbers to something familiar, they start to feel much more tangible, almost palpable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Angélique Kidjo Connects With Africa’s Next Musical Generation
description: The artist from Benin showed African songwriters how to reach the world. Now they’re repaying the favor.
content: Angélique Kidjo, the singer from Benin who has been forging Pan-African and transcontinental hybrids for three decades, didn’t really need another Grammy.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Could the U.S. have saved lives?
content: For all of the United States’ success with its vaccine rollout, about 100,000 people have died since February, when the rollout was underway. Many more were infected, hospitalized and are living with long-term problems.

content: Lordstown Motors, the struggling electric vehicle start-up, told securities regulators on Thursday that it did not have “binding” orders for a pickup truck it was developing, correcting statements made by its president on Tuesday.

title: As Astronauts Dock, China Takes Up Long-Term Residence in Orbit
description: Three Chinese astronauts arrived on Thursday to help build their country’s rival to the International Space Station.
content: Three Chinese astronauts docked with the country’s still-under-construction space station on Thursday, beginning what their government expects will be a decade or more of continuous presence by Chinese astronauts in Earth’s orbit.

title: Want a Completely Private Destination Wedding? Rent a Resort.
description: With more couples looking to create a safer travel experience for their guests, hotels and resorts that offer buyout wedding options are seeing an increase in requests.

title: Juneteenth: 7 Events for Celebrating the Holiday in New York
description: On Saturday, many of the city’s cultural venues are holding performances and parties to mark the emancipation of enslaved African Americans.
content: As New York reopens, its cultural rhythms are creeping back in, with museums and music venues filling up and outdoor concerts popping up in parks. The city is emerging just in time for Juneteenth on Saturday.

title: Happy to Shun Showrooms, Millennials Storm the Car Market
description: Younger buyers are helping feed a growing field of app- and web-based services. Last year, millennials topped baby boomers for the first time as new-car buyers.
content: Contrary to popular belief, millennials don’t hate cars. They hate car dealerships.

title: Andrew Yang draws fire over debate comments on mental illness.
description: During the final Democratic primary debate in the mayor’s race, Mr. Yang asked whose rights should come first: those with mental illness, or everyone else.
content: The Democratic candidates for New York mayor clashed at Wednesday night’s debate over how to help those who showed signs of untreated mental illness on city streets.

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Luca’ Review: Calamari by Your Name
description: Pixar takes a trip to the Italian coast in this breezy, charming sea-monster story.
content: A lot of movies can be described as fish-out-of-water stories, but few quite as literally as “Luca.” The title character, voiced by Jacob Tremblay, is an aquatic creature who lives with his family off the Mediterranean coast of Italy. The undersea equivalent of a shepherd, tending an amusing flock of sheeplike fish, Luca has a natural curiosity that is piqued by his mother’s warnings about the dangers that await on dry land.

author: By Neil Irwin
title: The Economic Gauges Are Going Nuts. Jerome Powell Is Taking a Longer View.
description: Despite the current confusion, his outlook, based on hard lessons from the 2010s, is essentially optimistic.
content: The economy is changing so fast that just making sense of it is no easy task. Within a few months, the United States has gone from no jobs and depressed prices to widespread labor shortages and uncomfortably high inflation.

author: By Matt Wolf
title: Challenges Aplenty Onstage in London, With Some Fun Along the Way
description: As London venues reopen, theatergoers can choose to reckon with works like “The Death of a Black Man” or enjoy frothier fare from George Bernard Shaw.
content: LONDON — Intimations of mortality have weighed heavily on our minds during the pandemic, so what better work to reanimate the National Theater than “After Life,” a play set in a mysterious space between this world and the next?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather and Andrew Das
title: Denmark Falls to Belgium as Both Teams Cheer Christian Eriksen
description: Eriksen, who collapsed during a Euro 2020 game on Saturday, will have a defibrillator implanted, Denmark’s team doctor said.
content: The fans cheered for Christian Eriksen in Copenhagen’s streets and parks, and they called out his name in the stands at Parken Stadium. And, in the 10th minute, the players from Denmark and Belgium even stopped their match to cheer for him right alongside them.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trevor Noah: ‘We Live in a World Where Having a Conversation Is Punished’
description: Jane and the host of ‘The Daily Show’ sit down to discuss the death of nuance, cancel culture and talking to people you disagree with.
content: In this bonus episode of “The Argument,” Jane Coaston has an extended chat with the late-night host Trevor Noah. They discuss taking on the mantle of “The Daily Show” from Jon Stewart, cancel culture and why you can’t take old jokes out of the context of the society in which they were made.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The F.C.C. proposes further restrictions on Chinese telecom equipment.
description: The agency’s actions are a sign of bipartisan opposition to China’s providers of cutting-edge technology like Huawei and ZTE.
content: The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday proposed further restrictions on purchases of telecommunications equipment that pose national security risks, strengthening its opposition to Chinese providers of 5G wireless and other technologies.

author: By Josephine Wolff
title: How Should We Handle Ransom Payments to Hackers? Very Carefully.
description: Efforts to reclaim extorted money  must go hand-in-hand with regulations on insurers.
content: The announcement last week that U.S. law enforcement officials had managed to recover $2.3 million of the roughly $4.4 million ransom that Colonial Pipeline paid hackers was a welcome development. But it also raised questions about who should bear the costs of ransom payments as the threat of online extortion grows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley, Iyad Abuheweila and Evan Hill
title: Dreams in the Rubble: An Israeli Airstrike and the 22 Lives Lost
description: The bombing of a Gaza apartment building has become a focus of debate over civilian casualties in the Hamas-Israel war. For the people who lived there, it was much more than that.
content: GAZA CITY — As Israeli airstrikes hit Gaza City for the sixth night running, Dr. Ayman Abul Ouf climbed the stairs of the apartment block that his family built four decades ago, calmer than he had seemed all day. The Abul Ouf Building, nestled in a wealthy shopping district on Al Wahda Street, was the last place he thought Israel would hit.
source.name: The New York Times

title: In Sprint to Reopening, Sports Hits Pandemic Obstacles
description: There is perhaps no greater hurdle to a return to normalcy in sports than the hesitancy among some elite athletes to be vaccinated.
content: Fans are returning in droves to stadiums. Games and tournaments are proceeding with regularity. Sports officials are projecting confidence that the pandemic is in the rearview mirror.

title: Barred From Her Own Home: How a Tool for Fighting Domestic Abuse Fails

author: By Becky Hughes
title: The Espresso Martini Is Everywhere (Again)
description: As the world rebounds, so too does a storied ’90s cocktail.
content: One need only look at our 21st-century devices — or out our old-fashioned windows — to know that 1990s nostalgia has reached, maybe even surpassed, fever pitch: A TikTok from Alicia Silverstone with a “Clueless” reference has more than 40 million views; Olivia Rodrigo’s chart-topping “good 4 u” video was inspired by, she said, “cult ’90s feminist horror movies”; and the recent “Friends” reunion drove record sign-ups for HBO Max. And that’s not to mention the ’90s resurgence that’s been happening in fashion.

author: By Philip Galanes
title: My Son Is Being Bullied, and I Don’t Know What to Do
description: A reader weighs her teenager’s shame against her own silence.
content: My 14-year-old son and I went to watch my younger son play in a baseball tournament. My younger son is popular and athletic; my older son is not. He’s more creative and a little effeminate. When we walked onto the field with our folding chairs, someone (I couldn’t tell who) shouted a gay slur. Some people laughed, and my son was clearly mortified. I felt frozen and unsure of what to do. And that feeling has lasted all week: I haven’t raised the issue with my son for fear of further embarrassing him, but I want him to know that I’m here for him. How should I handle this?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Biden Signs Law Making Juneteenth a Federal Holiday

author: By Martha Schwendener
title: A Small Brazilian Photo Club That Reached for the Skyline
description: How a group of mostly amateur photographers helped develop Brazil’s modernist aesthetic.
content: Europe was exhausted after World War II, and Brazil was ready to pick up the slack. Dozens of artists had left Europe fleeing fascism, and Brazil’s government was ready to support ambitious cultural undertakings, reflected in museums devoted to modern art and the inauguration of the São Paulo Biennial in 1951. This enthusiasm for modern art and new technological forms like photography can be felt even in amateur clubs like Foto-Cine Clube Bandeirante (FCCB), founded in 1939 in São Paulo. A trailblazer in the avant-garde art scene but little known outside the country, the group takes center stage in the show “Fotoclubismo: Brazilian Modernist Photography, 1946-1964” at the Museum of Modern Art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Specter of Inflation
description: Is it haunting the U.S. economy?
content: Here’s a simple way to understand the recent rise in inflation: As the pandemic is receding in the U.S., demand for goods and services is rebounding more quickly than the supply of those same goods and services. And when demand outpaces supply, prices rise.

title: Five weeks before the Olympics, Tokyo’s state of emergency will be eased.

title: The C.E.O. of UPS on Voting Rights and Vaccine Delivery

content: Carol Tomé had retired. After more than two decades working at Home Depot, where she rose to become chief financial officer, Ms. Tomé stepped down in 2019 and settled into the kind of postprofessional existence enjoyed by very well-compensated executives. author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Rita Moreno: Just a Girl Who Decided to Go for It’ Review: An Icon’s Growing Pains
description: This paean to the trailblazing Puerto Rican actress is also a case study in the highs and lows of showbiz for a woman of color.
content: Most documentaries about famous people tend to be exercises in celebrity worship, and “Rita Moreno: Just a Girl Who Decided to Go for It” is no exception. Directed by Mariem Pérez Riera, the film is a portrait filled with dazzling archival footage and shorn of ambiguities and unflattering viewpoints. Yet it is not your average paean because Moreno, a trailblazing Puerto Rican actress whose career spans more than seven decades, is not your average star.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Miller
title: Touring Alaska in an R.V.
description: For a photographer based in Juneau, two Alaskan roads — the Glenn Highway and the Richardson Highway — formed the backbone of a stunning late-spring road trip.
content: The land yacht surged and swayed over frost heaves at 65 m.p.h., each bump nudging the seemingly physics-defying craft as it hurtled down the highway. The engine purred its way up and down topographic reliefs and, with little hesitation, roared to life to climb the steeper passes.

title: Corrections: June 17, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, June 17, 2021.
content: An article on Tuesday about the impact of recently passed voting legislation on people with disabilities misstated the given name of a Wisconsin state senator. He is Rob Cowles, not Ron Cowles. The article also included outdated descriptions of two bills in Wisconsin that had since been amended. The amended proposals would restrict who could return voters’ ballots on their behalf and weaken accommodations for “indefinitely confined” voters, but would not forbid voters with family in-state to have a person outside of their family return their ballot or require indefinitely confined voters to provide photo identification in all cases.
